title: 115_s2031
content: The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" authorizes the conveyance of certain Federal land in Louisiana for market value consideration. Key terms include Collins Camp Properties, Secretary of Agriculture, and State of Louisiana. SEC. 4. Authorization of conveyances, Kisatchie National Forest, Louisiana. The term "Collins Camp Properties" refers to a corporation in Louisiana. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The term "State" means the State of Louisiana. The Secretary may convey Federal land in Louisiana by quitclaim deed, including competitive sale methods. The land includes all Federal land within sec. 9, T. 10 N., R. 5 W., Winn Parish, and a 2.16-acre parcel in sec. 4, T. 10 N., R. 5 W., Winn Parish. The Federal land in Louisiana can be conveyed by quitclaim deed or other methods. It includes all land within sec. 9, T. 10 N., R. 5 W., Winn Parish, and a 2.16-acre parcel in sec. 4, T. 10 N., R. 5 W., Winn Parish. During a 1-year period after the Act's enactment, Collins Camp has the first right to purchase the land upon providing consideration. During a 1-year period after the Act's enactment, Collins Camp has the first right to purchase not more than 47.92 acres of Federal land in Louisiana, specifically the Collins Campsites in Winn Parish. The Secretary will convey, by quitclaim deed, to Collins Camp Properties the United States' right, title, and interest in not more than 47.92 acres of Federal land in Winn Parish, Louisiana, known as the Collins Campsites, and another parcel of Federal land. The Secretary may configure the land to maximize marketability. The Secretary may configure the Federal land for conveyance to maximize marketability or achieve management objectives. Terms and conditions for the conveyances will be established in the public interest. Consideration for the conveyance of Federal land under this Act shall be determined. The Secretary may configure Federal land for conveyance to maximize marketability or achieve management objectives. Terms and conditions for conveyances under this Act will be established in the public interest. Consideration for the conveyance of Federal land shall be in the form of cash and equal to the market value of the land being conveyed. The market value will be determined by an appraisal. The market value of Federal land conveyed under this Act will be determined by an appraisal conducted in accordance with specific standards or by competitive sale. The conveyance of Federal land under this Act must be appraised according to specific standards or sold competitively. Hazardous substances disclosure is required, but the Secretary is not obligated to remediate them. In any conveyance of Federal land under this Act, the Secretary must disclose hazardous substances but is not required to remediate them. This does not affect the application of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to the conveyances of Federal land. The Secretary must deposit proceeds from the sale of Federal land into a specific fund. The administration of the fund is governed by Public Law 90-171. Collins Camp Properties must pay appraisal and analysis costs for the conveyance of Federal land. Offers for land acquisition must include approval from Forest Service special use authorization holders. Collins Camp Properties must pay appraisal and analysis costs for acquiring Federal land. Offers for land acquisition must be accompanied by written approval from holders of Forest Service special use authorizations. The holder of a special use authorization must agree to relinquish it when Federal land is conveyed to Collins Camp Properties. If the holder fails to provide written authorization, Collins Camp Properties will administer the authorization until it expires.
